titleStmt.title: Local Synchronization of Chaotic Neural Networks With Sampled-Data and Saturating Actuators

affiliation.orgName: National Laboratory of Industrial Control Technology
School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering
He was a Lecturer with Heilongjiang University

analytic.title: Local Synchronization of Chaotic Neural Networks With Sampled-Data and Saturating Actuators

biblStruct.note: received May 7, 2013; revised December 16, 2013; accepted March 10, 2014.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper investigates the problem of local syn-1 chronization of chaotic neural networks with sampled-data and 2 actuator saturation. A new time-dependent Lyapunov functional 3 is proposed for the synchronization error systems. The advantage 4 of the constructed Lyapunov functional lies in the fact that it is 5 positive definite at sampling times but not necessarily between 6 sampling times, and makes full use of the available information 7 about the actual sampling pattern. A local stability condition of 8 the synchronization error systems is derived, based on which a 9 sampled-data controller with respect to the actuator saturation 10 is designed to ensure that the master neural networks and 11 slave neural networks are locally asymptotically synchronous. 12 Two optimization problems are provided to compute the desired 13 sampled-data controller with the aim of enlarging the set of 14 admissible initial conditions or the admissible sampling upper 15 bound ensuring the local synchronization of the considered 16 chaotic neural networks. A numerical example is used to demon-17 strate the effectiveness of the proposed design technique.

such as manifold-based method [12], impulsive control method [13], adaptive control [14], fuzzy control [15], timedelay feedback approach [16], and sampled-data control [17]. Accordingly, in the past decade, there has also been increasing research interest in the study of synchronization of chaotic neural networks [17]- [24]. For example, the problem of adaptive lag synchronization has been discussed for a kind of competitive neural network with mixed time-delays and hybrid perturbations in [19], where a simple but robust adaptive controller has been designed such that the response system can lag-synchronize with a drive system. In [21], a general discrete-time chaotic neural network model has been provided to unify several well-known dynamic neural networks with or without delays, and then based on the Lyapunov stability theory and linear matrix inequality (LMI) approach, time-delay feedback controllers have been designed to exponentially synchronize two general chaotic neural networks with different initial conditions and reduce the H ∞ -norm from the disturbance input to the output error within a lowest level. The robust exponential synchronization problem has been investigated in [22] for a class of chaotic delayed neural networks with different parametric uncertainties and a novel impulsive control scheme has been proposed, based on which a global exponential synchronization error bound together with some new sufficient conditions expressed in the form of LMIs has been proposed to ensure that the synchronization error dynamics can converge to a predetermined level.

Nowadays, in digitalized world, control systems are often controlled by digital controllers, that is, only the samples of the control input signals at discrete-time instants can be employed [25]. Actually, in the control community, the problems of sampled-data control and filter have been investigated in depth and a lot of important results have been proposed in the existing literature [26]- [34]. In the framework of the input delay approach, the problem of sampled-data synchronization has been studied for neural networks with discrete and distributed delays under variable sampling in [17], where the time-varying delay induced by sample-and-hold is simply treated as a bounded fast varying delay (it is a time-varying delay without any constraint on the delay derivative), that is, the sawtooth structure of the time-varying delay is neglected. In [24], the sampled-data synchronization problem of neural networks has been revisited via the time-dependent Lyapunov functional approach, and some improved synchronization criteria have been derived. It should be pointed out that the time-dependent Lyapunov functional approach was first introduced in [26] 2168-2267 c 2014 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

to discuss the problem of sampled-data control of linear systems. The advantage of such method lies in the fact that it takes into account the sawtooth evolution of the timevarying delay induced by sample-and-hold, which implies that more information about the actual sampling pattern is utilized. Thus, the presented work of [24] significantly reduces the conservatism of the results of [17]. The problem of stochastic synchronization has been investigated for Markov jump neural networks with time-varying delay and samplings in [35], where two sufficient conditions have been proposed that the master systems stochastically synchronize with the slave systems by the input delay approach and time-dependent Lyapunov functional approach, respectively. The results of [35] can be viewed as the extension of existing results on neural networks proposed in [24] to Markov jump neural networks. Very recently, in [36], the problem of sampled-data control for synchronization schemes that consist of identical chaotic Lur'e systems with time delays, which cover chaotic neural networks as special case, has been discussed, and a new time-dependent Lyapunov functional, which is positive definite at sampling times but not necessarily positive definite inside the sampling intervals, has been given. Based on the Lyapunov functional, a synchronization criterion has been derived for the design of the desired sampled-data controller.

On the other hand, a great deal of attention has been focused on the analysis and synthesis of controllers for dynamic systems subject to actuator saturation. It has been shown that actuator saturation inevitably degrades the performance and does harm to stability of a closed-loop system if the controller is designed without considering this kind of saturation nonlinearity. There are mainly two approaches to deal with saturation nonlinearity. The first one is to utilize a local sector bound nonlinearity to describe the saturation nonlinearity [37]- [41],

while the second one is the polytopic representation of saturation nonlinearity [42]- [44]. Very recently, in [45], an improved treatment of saturation nonlinearity has been proposed, which covers the polytopic representation as a special case. Based on the results of [26] and [27], the stabilization problem has been revisited for sampled and saturated controlled systems in [41], where a novel constructive stabilization criterion has been proposed by using the discrete-time Lyapunov theorem.

In this paper, we will design sampled-data controller (7) such that the master system (1) and slave system (3) are locally asymptotically synchronous, that is, given a set E(P), the corresponding trajectory of system (15) converges asymptotically to the origin for any initial condition r(t 0 ) ∈ E(P). In this case, the set E(P) is called the domain of attraction of system (15).

Remark 1: In the presence of saturation, the global stabilization of system (15) cannot be realized [40], that is, the master system (1) and slave system (3) cannot achieve global synchronization. Therefore, we consider the local synchronization instead of the global synchronization. It is noted that the exact analytical determination of the domain of attraction of system ( 15) is, in general, not possible, and thus we are concerned with the determination of estimates of the domain of attraction E(P).

div.head: III. Main Results
div.p: In this section, inspired by the idea of [41], we first give a sufficient condition, which ensures the master system (1) and slave system (3) that are locally asymptotically synchronous, as follows.

Thus, for any initial condition r(t 0 ) ∈ E(P), the corresponding trajectory of system ( 15) converges asymptotically to the origin, that is, the master system (1) and slave system (3) are locally asymptotically synchronous. This completes the proof.

Remark 2: It is noted that in Theorem 1, a local synchronization criterion is proposed for the considered chaotic neural networks in the presence of actuator saturation, which is dependent on both the upper and lower bounds of the sampling periods. It should be pointed out that some sampleddata synchronization criteria for chaotic neural networks can also be found in [24], [35], and [36], but the effect of actuator saturation on synchronization of chaotic neural networks has not been considered in [24], [35], and [36]. Moreover, the results obtained in [24], [35], and [36] only depend upon the upper bound of sampling periods, while the lower bound of sampling periods is neglected, which may lead to conservative results.

Next, we will cast the proposed theoretical condition in Theorem 2 into LMI-based optimization problems to find a suitable sampled-data controller (7) for different requirements. Specifically, the following two cases are considered. 1) Given h 1 and h 2 , find a sampled-data controller gain matrix K and a set E(X -T PX -1 ), as large as possible, for which the locally asymptotical synchronization of the master system (1) and slave system (3) is ensured. 2) Given h 1 and a set of admissible initial conditions, find a sampled-data controller gain matrix K and the largest sampling upper bound h 2 , for which the locally asymptotical synchronization of the master system (1) and slave system (3) is ensured.

To address the above-mentioned two cases, we introduce a set E (W R ). It is clear that the aim of Case 1 is to maximize the set E (X -T PX -1 ), which can be accomplished if α is maximized, where the scalar α is such that

Remark 4: It should be mentioned that the master system (1) has the same parameter matrices as the slave system (3), but adopting similar techniques used in this paper and [46], we can also propose the corresponding results for chaotic neural networks with parameter mismatches.

div.head: IV. Numerical Example
div.p: In this section, we will demonstrate the advantages and effectiveness of the proposed methods in this paper via an example. Consider a chaotic neural network consisting of three neurons [18], is adopted as both the master and slave systems with the following parameters:

Under the gain matrix K given in (64), the response of error system ( 15) is depicted in Fig. 3, from which we find that the trajectory of system (15) converges to the origin eventually, that is, the master system (1) and slave system (3) are synchronous.

div.head: V. Conclusion
div.p: This paper investigated the problem of sampled-data synchronization related to chaotic neural networks, which includes actuator saturations. Based on a new time-dependent Lyapunov functional, a condition that allows the computation of a sampled-data controller associated with a set of admissible initial conditions, for which the local synchronization of the master neural networks and slave neural networks can be ensured, have been derived. Based on the presented conditions, two optimization problems have been given to compute the desired sampled-data controller gain aiming at: maximizing the set of admissible initial conditions or the admissible sampling upper bound. A numerical example has been given to illustrate the potentials of the proposed design techniques. In our future work, we will further consider the problem of sampled-data synchronization under actuator saturations for more complex chaotic neural networks, such as chaotic neural networks with time delay, chaotic switched neural networks, and chaotic neural networks with missing data and/or quantization.

II. Preliminaries
Consider the following chaotic neural network:
Although the importance of actuator saturation has been
widely recognized, no related results have been established
for the synchronization of chaotic neural networks with time-
varying sampling. The main purpose of this paper, therefore,
is to linkage such a gap by making the first attempt to deal
with the problem of local synchronization of chaotic neural
networks with sampled-data and saturating actuators.
In this paper, the local synchronization problem is ad-
dressed for chaotic neural networks with time-varying sam-
pling subject to actuator saturations. Following the idea pro-
posed in [41], a local stability condition is derived for the
synchronization error systems via a novel time-dependent
Lyapunov functional, which is positive definite at sampling
times but not necessarily between sampling times. Based on
the Lyapunov functional, a local stability condition is derived
for the synchronization error systems. Such type of Lyapunov
functional makes full use of the available information about
